ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I experienced all-round improvement in Persian, especially in speaking and writing.
I greatly developed my persian vocabulary and also learned many new verb tense that allowed me to speak about different time periods. I also learned about Persian culture, such as Eid Nowruz!
Improved persian ability

I learned how to write and read in Farsi, construct sentences in the past, present, future, and subjunctive, speak with commands, etc. I also learned vocabulary about university life, technology, directions/travel, food, learning, clothing, weather, shopping, etc. And I learned a lot about Persian culture and history.
I developed continuing knowledge of Persian language and culture, especially topics relating to the weather and COVID-19.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course has a very high degree of participation, and includes a lot of practices of the language. It can be improved if there are more instructions about how should we review and memorize the words.

This course was taken via Zoom during the COVID pandemic, making it not a very fair assessment of the true quality of the course. However, I still enjoyed coming to class everyday and I learned a lot. Ostad (the professor) has very reasonable expectations and was very understanding, ensuring that we were learning first and foremost!
Its not easy to learn a language on Zoom
The course is very strong. I have tried to take Farsi classes before and none were as good as this one. I feel like I really learned a lot and became more comfortable with the language.

The main strength is that Ostad has no tolerance for messing around you need to work hard in the class, or you won't do well, and I think that's great. One of the weaknesses, I think, is the textbook other universities use books with much more vocabulary, and I feel I would be better able to express myself with a more official text. (But I don't learn well unless I am under extreme duress so that could just be me.)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion format succeeded and the effect is pretty good.

The seminar/discussion style helped, because it kept me focused and engaged. It also allowed me to connect with my peers. I think certain writing assignments were a little difficult because of the inability to go to office hours.

Many of the practices worked well. We used breakout rooms to write dialogues with partners, and then we presented the dialogues to the class. We also met with partners outside of class time to write longer dialogues and present them to class. The teacher had a whiteboard that she used to show us how to write different words. The TA played games with us during language table that were accessible virtually, which was fun and helped us learn to read quickly.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want to learn Persian, this class is definitely a good choice. It will push you to really take a grasp of the language.
1000%. Persian is an ancient language and the ability to speak/understand it will be valuable for anybody interested in near-east literature or middle-eastern politics.
Yes, anyone who has ever thought about learning Farsi should take the opportunity to learn from Ostad Shayesteh.
Yes! Learning Persian can be beneficial for everything ranging from national security to personal interest, and Ostad teaches very well.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday there are classes. And on Friday there will be another language table which is in virtual discussion format.
Asynchronous, idependent homework days

The class was virtual due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The format was a virtual seminar, with lots of class participation. Every student spoke multiple times in every class. Once every week, we also had a "language table," which was a more informal conversation with the TA and the students where we learned additional vocabulary and grammar and practiced speaking.
